lom:description.lom:string:
"The EECS Department offers undergraduate degrees in Computer Engineering, Computer Science, and Electrical Engineering. There are more than 800 declared students in the program (students do not declare as freshmen), and last year 500 degrees were awarded. Undergraduate students are given the opportunity to work with faculty, and often offer significant contributions to the research.
Between strong demand and rapid turnover, jobs abound for good systems and applications programmers, hardware designers, network managers, and consultants in many areas. Computer scientists and engineers make the Web faster, improve the machines we use, design and build PDAs like the Palm, and iPAQ. CE/CS majors also provide the computational power underlying fields as varied as oil exploration, health care, airplane design, and weather modeling. Applications programmers are responsible for writing instructions to solve specific scientific or commercial problems. Systems programmers develop software which makes computer programming and operations simpler."

lom:title.lom:string: Undergraduate Computer Engineering Curriculum - University of Michigan
